item.title: Japan Protests After Chinese Ships Linger in Disputed Waters
item.description: Since September, Chinese ships have made regular visits into the waters as part of what analysts call a long-term strategy of wearing down Japan’s will to keep enforcing its claims.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Study Suggests North Korea Is Doubling Area Devoted to Uranium Enrichment
item.description: The expansion of the Yongbyon reactor complex was reported amid talk of easing tension with South Korea and the United States.
item.category: Institute for Science and International Security
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and GERRY MULLANY

item.title: India Ink: The Battles for Gorkhaland
item.description: Political agitation for a separate state of Gorkhaland intensifies in West Bengal’s Darjeeling.
item.dc:creator: By SATYABRAT SINHA
item.media:description: Supporters of the Gorkha People's Liberation Front, shouting slogans, as they pay tribute to Mangal Singh Rajput, a Gorkha leader who self immolated on July 30. and died three days later.

item.title: Ties Fraying, Obama Drops Putin Meeting
item.description: The sides have been at loggerheads over arms control, missile defense, Syria, trade and human rights, and Obama aides said Moscow was no longer responding to their proposals.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:description: President Obama and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at the end of their meeting in Enniskillen, Northern Ireland, in June.

item.title: Mine Deal Puts New Scrutiny on China’s State Industries
item.description: A rare glimpse into a 2010 deal to purchase three mines in Shanxi Province has raised stark questions about the power of China’s state enterprises.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: China’s Zhongshe coal mine has been shuttered since 2010.

item.title: John Woodward, Leader of British Navy in Falkland Islands War, Dies at 81
item.description: Admiral Woodward, as commander of a Royal Navy battle group in 1982, gave the order to sink the Argentine cruiser General Belgrano.
item.dc:creator: By RICHARD GOLDSTEIN
item.media:description: Adm. John Woodward, right, the naval commander, in July 1982 with Maj. Gen. Jeremy Moore, who led ground forces.

item.title: Japan Stepping In to Help Clean Up Atomic Plant
item.description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe called for intervention as concern grew over new contamination from the Fukushima Daiichi plant into the Pacific Ocean.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: A worker walking near water tanks at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant in Japan.

item.title: Linking Factories to the Malls, Middleman Pushes Low Costs
item.description: The Hong Kong-based company Li & Fung is a matchmaker between poor countries’ factories and affluent nations’ vendors. But critics call it the garment industry’s “sweatshop locator.”
item.dc:creator: By IAN URBINA and KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: Demonstrators outside Li & Fung in Hong Kong last year protesting what they said were unpaid wages owed to textile workers in Turkey.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Détente Over Gibraltar Sought
item.description: Britain and Spain have agreed to try to defuse tensions over the contested British overseas territory of Gibraltar, Prime Minister David Cameron’s office said Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: After Delays, Stranded Migrants Land
item.description: Italy on Wednesday allowed 102 migrants, mainly from North Africa and stranded on a tanker in the Mediterranean, to debark on the coast of Sicily.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Life Lessons From a Most Unlikely Duo
item.description: A tragedy brought a wealthy mother and a drug smuggler together in Colombia, and their story offers an inspiring lesson for others.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF

item.title: Silence Underground
item.description: Rare questions are being asked about the power of state-owned corporations as details emerge about the purchase of three mines in Shanxi Province.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: China’s Zhongshe coal mine has been shuttered since 2010.

item.title: Dispute Over Value-Added Tax on Movie Tickets in China Appears Near End
item.description: While working on a resolution, the China Film Group has held up payments to American studios for the distribution in China of blockbusters like “Skyfall.”
item.category: Office of the United States Trade Representative
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL CIEPLY and BROOKS BARNES
item.media:description: Chinese censors withdrew their approval of Quentin Tarantino’s “Django Unchained,” a bloody historical drama.

item.title: Tunis Journal: A Cafe Where the Spirit of the Arab Spring Lives On
item.description: The Théâtre de l’Étoile du Nord is not just a popular cafe in the Tunisian capital, but also a haunt for actors, intellectuals, freethinkers and revolutionaries, and it never closes.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Actors relaxing in the dressing room of the Théâtre de l’Étoile du Nord, a freewheeling cafe and dramatic space in Tunis.

item.title: Hollande Vows to Tackle Rising Unemployment, but the French Are Skeptical
item.description: The French president’s high hopes of beginning to reverse the country’s No. 1 problem by the end of the year have been met with pessimism.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: President François Hollande visiting an employment center, where he was confronted by an unemployed Frenchwoman.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: From Maoist Criminal to Popular Hero?
item.description: Officials hope the trial of Bo Xilai will put a full stop to the party’s most embarrassing political scandal in decades. But even if the trial goes as planned, Mr. Bo could end up an unlikely hero.
item.dc:creator: By PIN HO

item.title: Caustic Light on White House’s Reaction to a Terrorist Threat
item.description: The decision to shut some American diplomatic posts in the Middle East has prompted gloating among jihadists and criticism by some officials who say the Obama administration overreacted.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT F. WORTH and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Yemen, on Alert for Terrorism, Says It Foiled a Qaeda Plot
item.description: Yemeni officials said they had thwarted a plan to kidnap or kill foreigners working at an oil terminal, but the claim aroused skepticism among terrorism analysts.
item.dc:creator: By NASSER ARRABYEE and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: A police officer patrolled Wednesday by the airport in Sana, Yemen.

item.title: Study Suggests North Korea Is Doubling Area Devoted to Uranium Enrichment
item.description: The expansion of the Yongbyon reactor complex was reported amid talk of easing tension with South Korea and the United States.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and GERRY MULLANY
item.media:description: South Korean workers and owners who run factories in the shuttered Kaesong industrial complex staged a rally on Wednesday near the border village of Panmunjom to ask for the resumption of operations at Kaesong.

item.title: Jordan Says It’s Questioning Two Syrians on Arms
item.description: The Syrians were detained and accused of trying to smuggle missiles and assault rifles into the country, a security official said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Venezuelan Court Rejects Challenge to Presidential Election Results
item.description: The court also ordered Henrique Capriles, who lost to Nicolás Maduro, to pay a fine for insulting government authority by accusing the judicial system of bias.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: Henrique Capriles lost his legal challenges to the April presidential election results.

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Cache of Ivory Is Seized
item.description: Hong Kong customs officials seized an illegal shipment of ivory tusks, rhino horns and leopard skins worth more than $5 million, officials said Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Togo: Major Ivory Trader Is Arrested
item.description: A major ivory trafficker who activists say has fueled the slaughter of more than 10,000 elephants was arrested in Togo, the environment minister said Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Catholic Church Says Army Killed Unarmed Protesters
item.description: The Roman Catholic Church in Sri Lanka accused the military on Wednesday of shooting unarmed protesters last week and desecrating a church.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Farmers Smash Eggs in Protest
item.description: A group of French farmers has gone on an egg-breaking rampage on roads and pledging to smash many more in protest against low prices.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE
